subject: polity
title: Budget Process & Grants (Art 112-116)
description: Detailed coverage of Union Budget process, constitutional provisions, stages of enactment, and types of grants

provisions: President shall cause to be laid before Parliament **Annual Financial Statement** (Budget) for each financial year
Financial Year: **1st April to 31st March** (changed from 1st Jan-31st Dec in 1867 by British)
Budget shows **estimated receipts & expenditure** of Government for the financial year
Budget distinguishes between **Charged** expenditure (non-votable) and **Voted** expenditure (votable by LS)
scope: **Receipts**: Revenue receipts (taxes, non-tax) + Capital receipts (borrowings, disinvestment)
**Expenditure**: Revenue expenditure (salaries, subsidies) + Capital expenditure (infrastructure, assets)
**Charged on Consolidated Fund** (Art 112(3)): Not voted by Parliament - President, Judges, CAG salaries, Debt charges, etc.
**Voted by Lok Sabha**: All other expenditure - Demands for Grants (Art 113)
significance: Most important parliamentary control over executive - 'No taxation without representation'
Lok Sabha controls public purse - Approves taxes & expenditure
Budget reflects government's priorities & policies for the year
Fiscal accountability ensured through detailed scrutiny by Parliament
examTips: Art 112 - Annual Financial Statement (NOT called 'Budget' in Constitution)
Financial Year: 1st April - 31st March (changed in 1867 during British rule)
Charged vs Voted: Charged (Art 112(3)) NOT voted (President, Judges, CAG, Debt); Voted by LS (Demands for Grants)
Budget = Financial Statement + Demands for Grants + Appropriation Bill + Finance Bill

provisions: **Finance Minister** presents budget in Lok Sabha (usually last week of February)
**Budget Speech**: FM explains financial position, tax proposals, expenditure priorities
**Budget Documents**: Annual Financial Statement, Demands for Grants, Finance Bill, Economic Survey, etc.
**Halwa Ceremony** marks printing of budget documents (lock-in of officials begins)
scope: Budget presented in **Lok Sabha first** (Money Bill provision)
**Railway Budget** was separate till 2017; Now merged with General Budget
**Economic Survey** presented day before budget (overview of economy)
**Union Budget** covers all receipts, expenditure, taxation proposals for the year
significance: FM's budget speech outlines government's economic vision
Parliament gets detailed financial information for scrutiny
Public & businesses get clarity on tax rates, subsidies, schemes
Markets react to budget proposals (stock market, currency)
examTips: Budget presented in **Lok Sabha** (Money Bill - only LS can vote on financial matters)
No voting on Budget Speech - Just presentation & general discussion
Railway Budget merged in 2017 (earlier separate since 1924)
Budget date changed from Feb 28 to Feb 1 in 2017 for early implementation

provisions: After budget presentation, **General Discussion** in both Houses
Members discuss overall budget, economic policies, allocation priorities
**No voting** at this stage - Only discussion & suggestions
Discussion can last several days (typically 4-5 days)
scope: Broad discussion on: Fiscal deficit, revenue targets, tax proposals, sectoral allocations
Opposition criticizes government's economic management & priorities
Government defends its policies & budget proposals
Both LS and RS participate (though RS can't vote on budget)
significance: Allows comprehensive review of government's fiscal policies
Opposition raises concerns about deficit, debt, inflation, unemployment
Public debate on economic priorities (welfare vs growth, subsidies vs infrastructure)
Media coverage ensures public awareness of government's plans
examTips: General Discussion in **both Houses** (not just LS)
No voting at this stage - Only policy discussion
Fiscal Deficit, Revenue Deficit, Primary Deficit are key terms discussed
FRBM Act (2003) mandates fiscal discipline targets

provisions: **Art 113**: Expenditure (except Charged) must be voted by Lok Sabha as **Demands for Grants**
Each Ministry/Department presents its demand (total 109 demands in 2024)
**Standing Committees** scrutinize demands & submit reports
LS can **reduce or reject** a demand, but **cannot increase** it (Art 113(3))
scope: **Votable Expenditure**: All expenditure except Charged (salaries, schemes, subsidies, development)
Members can move **Cut Motions** to reduce/modify demands:
• **Policy Cut**: Disapprove policy (demand reduced to Re 1)
• **Economy Cut**: Reduce demand by specific amount (economy can be made)
• **Token Cut**: Discuss specific grievance (demand reduced by Rs 100)
significance: **Most crucial** parliamentary control - LS decides where money is spent
Cut Motions are opposition's tool to criticize govt policies & expenditure
Standing Committees provide detailed scrutiny (30+ members per committee)
If demand rejected, that Ministry cannot spend (govt may fall)
examTips: Art 113 - Demands for Grants voted ONLY by **Lok Sabha** (RS has no role)
LS can **reduce/reject** but **cannot increase** demand (Art 113(3))
**Cut Motions**: Policy Cut (Re 1), Economy Cut (specific amount), Token Cut (Rs 100 to discuss grievance)
**Guillotine**: If all demands not voted by deadline, all pending demands deemed passed (time limit enforcement)

provisions: **Art 114**: No money can be withdrawn from Consolidated Fund without Parliament's **Appropriation**
After Demands for Grants passed, **Appropriation Bill** introduced
This bill **authorizes** government to withdraw approved amounts from Consolidated Fund
It is a **Money Bill** - LS only; RS has 14 days to recommend
scope: **Appropriation** = Legal authorization to spend money already voted by LS
Without Appropriation Act, government **cannot withdraw money** from Consolidated Fund
Covers both **Charged** (included but not voted) and **Voted** expenditure
Once passed, becomes **Appropriation Act** - Law for that financial year
significance: Final legal authority for government to spend public money
Ensures money is spent only for purposes approved by Parliament
Fundamental principle: **No expenditure without parliamentary authorization**
Violation of Appropriation Act is illegal & punishable
examTips: Art 114 - **Appropriation Bill** gives legal authority to spend money from Consolidated Fund
It is a **Money Bill** - All Money Bill provisions apply (only LS, 14 days RS)
Appropriation Bill **cannot be amended** (no changes to amounts already voted)
Difference: Demands for Grants = **Voting** on amounts; Appropriation Bill = **Legal authorization** to withdraw

provisions: **Finance Bill** contains government's taxation proposals (new taxes, tax rate changes)
Introduced after Appropriation Bill
It is a **Money Bill** under Art 110 (deals with taxation)
LS can amend Finance Bill; RS can only recommend (14 days)
scope: **Taxation changes**: Income Tax, GST, Customs Duty, Excise Duty rate changes
**New taxes** or abolition of existing taxes
**Non-tax revenue** measures (fees, fines increases)
Finance Bill passed **before 31st March** (to ensure new tax rates apply from 1st April)
significance: Implements government's tax policy for the year
Affects every citizen/business (income tax slabs, GST rates, customs duty)
Revenue generation tool - Taxes fund government expenditure
Economic policy instrument - Lower taxes (stimulus), Higher taxes (revenue collection)
examTips: Finance Bill is a **Money Bill** (Art 110 - taxation)
Presented **after** Appropriation Bill (first authorize spending, then raise revenue)
Must be passed before 31st March for implementation from 1st April
LS can amend; RS only recommends (14 days)

provisions: **Supplementary Grant (Art 115(1)(a))**: Additional funds needed during the year for unforeseen expenditure
**Additional Grant (Art 115(1)(b))**: More funds needed due to excess expenditure beyond voted/charged amount
**Excess Grant (Art 115(1)(c))**: Post-facto grant to regularize excess expenditure (after financial year ends)
**Vote of Credit (Art 116(1))**: Grants for undefined purpose when details cannot be stated (emergency, defense)
scope: **Exceptional Grant (Art 116(2))**: Grants forming no part of current service of financial year (new service)
**Token Grant (Art 116(3))**: Grant of nominal amount (Re 1) to introduce new policy/service (full grant sought later)
**Vote on Account (Art 116)**: Grant to meet expenditure for part of financial year (before full budget passed)
All these grants follow same procedure as Demands for Grants (voted by LS)
significance: Provide **flexibility** to government for unforeseen needs (disasters, wars, urgent schemes)
**Vote on Account** ensures continuity - Govt doesn't shut down if budget delayed (election year)
**Excess Grant** ensures accountability - CAG audits, PAC examines, Parliament regularizes
**Vote of Credit** gives broad powers but rarely used (last used in Kargil War 1999)
examTips: **Supplementary** = Additional funds **during** the year; **Excess** = Regularization **after** year ends
**Vote of Credit**: Broad grant, no details (defense, emergency); Rarely used (Kargil 1999)
**Vote on Account**: For **part of year** (2-4 months); Used in election year; Authorized by Art 116
All grants are **voted by LS only** (like Demands for Grants); RS has no voting power

provisions: **Policy Cut Motion**: Demand reduced to **Re 1** - Expresses disapproval of policy underlying the demand
**Economy Cut Motion**: Demand reduced by **specific amount** - Economy can be made in expenditure
**Token Cut Motion**: Demand reduced by **Rs 100** - To discuss specific grievance about policy/administration
scope: Cut Motions moved by members **during Demands for Grants** discussion
Can be moved **only in Lok Sabha** (not in RS)
If Cut Motion passed, government may face **no-confidence** situation (depends on motion type)
Opposition uses Cut Motions to **highlight failures** & force debate on specific issues
significance: Important tool for **opposition** to criticize government
Forces government to defend its policies & expenditure priorities
**Policy Cut** is most serious - If passed, government's policy rejected (may fall)
**Token Cut** most used - Allows raising constituency grievances & local issues
examTips: **Policy Cut** = Re 1 (disapprove policy); **Economy Cut** = Specific amount (reduce expenditure); **Token Cut** = Rs 100 (discuss grievance)
Only in **Lok Sabha** during **Demands for Grants**
Policy Cut most serious (govt's policy rejected); Token Cut most frequently used
Cut Motions rarely passed (govt has majority) but allow opposition to raise issues
keyCases: No landmark cases on Cut Motions (procedural matter within Parliament)
